conclusion: To determine whether Car A is ahead of or behind Car B at \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \), we need to analyze the displacement of each car from \( t = 0 \, \text{s} \) to \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \). The displacement of a car can be calculated as the area under its velocity-time (\( v-t \)) graph over the given time interval.
Car A has a constant velocity of \( 40 \, \text{m/s} \) starting from \( t = 0 \, \text{s} \).
Car B starts from rest (\( v = 0 \)) and accelerates linearly, reaching \( v = 40 \, \text{m/s} \) at \( t = 20 \, \text{s} \).

premise: Car A has a constant velocity of \( 40 \, \text{m/s} \) from \( t = 0 \, \text{s} \) to \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \).
conclusion: Since Car A has a constant velocity, its displacement is the area of a rectangle under the graph from \( t = 0 \, \text{s} \) to \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \).

premise: The rectangle has a height of \( 40 \, \text{m/s} \) and a width of \( 10 \, \text{s} \).
Car B's velocity increases linearly, forming a triangle under the graph from \( t = 0 \, \text{s} \) to \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \).
conclusion: The triangle has a base of \( 10 \, \text{s} \) and a height of \( 20 \, \text{m/s} \) (since Car B's velocity at \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \) is \( 20 \, \text{m/s} \)).

premise: The triangle has a base of \( 10 \, \text{s} \) and a height of \( 20 \, \text{m/s} \).
At \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \), Car A has traveled \( 400 \, \text{m} \), while Car B has traveled \( 100 \, \text{m} \).
conclusion: Therefore, Car A is ahead of Car B at \( t = 10 \, \text{s} \).
